intro: Ptilotus whitei, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its unique, fluffy seed heads that resemble clouds or ghosts, hence its common name. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid regions, thriving in sandy soils. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are often pale green or yellow, which are followed by the distinctive, showy seed heads. Ptilotus whitei is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional Aboriginal practices.
